Castling, something I probably should do too. His monarch is completely safe, especially since his dark-squared comfortably controls the long diagonal. Well, we'll see who ends up being master of the long diagonal!

While this allows a combination of sorts, I figured black would refrain from playing it since it weakens the back rank and the long diagonal considerably.
No, he does play it.

He probably did not expect me to play this, since I seem to be giving my rook away. But I can at least grab his bishop after 16. Qe8+ and 17. Qxc8 or try to mate him with 16. Bh6 even though no direct mate is available since his queen controls the long diagonal.

While this looks like I'm offering a trade of queens, that was not my intention and not in my best interest either. I figured he wouldn't trade queens since he's behind in material. I did this to take control of some important squares.

? Not such a useful place for the queen. Nothing is threatened and he removes his queen from the defense of his king, which is already feeling a cold draught since his bishop left.
Threatening to take over the long diagonal, with real mating options on g7.
More or less forced. This move makes sure that my queen cannot venture to h6.
Yeah, I control the long diagonal!
I would like my queen to take place on f6. His completely useless light-squared bishop blocks 22 ...f5. His knight and queen are also far away from the defense of their king.
